data.text: Can I Convert a MTB into a Gravel Bike?

New member and also a very new cyclist. So far I am doing alot of 30-40 mi city/countryside rides. I want to get into gravel bikes but currently I would rather hold off on buying a while new bike. Does anyone have any experience in converting a MTB into a gravel bike? Is it frowned upon? If so, why?

Just get a low rolling resistance tire, something with a minimal tread, and roll them kinda high as far as inflation goes, unless the surface you're riding requires a lower pressure and send it!!! "Every bike is a gravel bike, except for gravel bikes, those are just 80's mountain bikes with drop bars."- Every cyclist page comment section expert funny man.
data.author: Kenneth Rieck

data.text: This is what I'm currently running...I got the least knobby tires they had that would fit my rim at the specialized store. The higher pressure is to avoid punctures right?
data.author: Derek Mills

data.text: the higher the pressure the lower your contact patch with the ground, meaning the lower the resistance of rolling on said ground, if you're trying to avoid punctures from hard objects (pinch flats) you actually want lower pressure.
data.author: Kenneth Rieck

data.text: so if I plan to hop a bunch of curbs in the city I need lower pressure?
data.author: Derek Mills

data.text: No. To prevent pinch flats you need higher pressure. Not lower. It's a balancing act to get low enough pressure for comfort and traction but high enough to reduce friction and prevent rim strikes.
data.author: Chad Ashton

data.text: love it - every bike is a gravel bike except gravel bikes. Man, that nails it 100%. Big Brand Gravel bikes have somehow morphed into skinny guy lycra wearing race bikes with slightly fatter tires. Thanks goodness we still have all the weird small brands for the rest of us who could give a shi+ about KOM's and all the rest of it.
data.author: Chris Summers

data.text: A set of rigid forks will save some weight, making a faster rolling machine. MTBs tend to feel a bit draggy on tarmac, but with more control on rougher stuff. If you run tubeless then tyre pressure can be lower, less chance of pinch flats if you slam a curb!
data.author: Owain Jones

data.text: I am currently tubed with a spare tube in my bag because I'm nervous that a random flat could be more detrimental to my ride on tubeless? How do you fix a tubeless flat on the go?
data.author: Derek Mills

data.text: if it's a small puncture like a thorn, then the sealant in the tyre should seal the hole. For larger holes, or one that won't seal then you can get plugs to push through the tyre, like dyna-plug or Stan's dart. Just went on a 5 day trip, my friend had 2 punctures and had to change tubes, I had 1, that I didn't even know about until I got home (sealant on the frame). I still take a spare tube, just in case I can't get the tyre to seal.

data.author: Derek Mills

data.text: it can work fine but the geometry is different - usually a longer top tube, maybe a shorter seat tube and lower overall stack. I've converted old hybrids, touring bikes, and cyclocross bikes. A bike that clears bigger tires is all you really need.
data.author: Chris Summers

data.text: You can definitely ride gravel on a mountain bike; it’ll just be a bit slower. Changing out the wheels and tires, converting to drop bar front end, and swapping out drivetrain components for faster ratios will help make it more gravel bikey but it will always be a bit clunkier than a gravel oriented bike, and can cost close to the same as an entry level gravel bike. I’d just ride the MTB on gravel for a while until you decide you want to get into gravel racing or have another reason to care about your speed, and then get a gravel bike.
data.author: Stephen Brown

data.text: A hardtail mountain bike is a pretty ideal gravel bike. I ride by Santa Cruz Highball on gravel more than my Giant TCX.
data.author: Mike Lamarca

data.text: You could put a narrower, smoother rolling tire on and 80-100mm narrower stanchion fork to save weight. I personally had 2 different gravel bikes but like the more upright mtb position and front suspension so went back to a hardtail.
data.author: Brandi Jackson Hodges

data.text: Works great. I have a both Trek Checkpoint and I converted my old Haro FLC XC bike to a 'do everything' rig and it is my favorite bike. I found everything used: 105 shifters (free), XT 9sp rear derailleur ($65 and works with 10sp shifters), TRP brakes ($120 new), 50mm stem to shorten reach ($30). I have raced the Haro and the trek on the same course and the time difference over 65 miles was just under 5 mins.
data.author: Mike Kavan

data.text: MTBs are fine for gravel. If anyone is frowning at you because of your bike, don’t ride with them. They’re a jerk.
data.author: Philip Rohrer

data.text: A MTB is a gravel bike...if you're not happy with the tires as being the best for gravel...do a tire swap....If you want a good do-it-all fast XC tire, the Maxxis Ikon or Vittoria Mezcal are very good.
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: I am actually more dissatisfied with the wide handle bars. I am not seeing how cost inefficient it is to change that many components on a traditional MTB so I'm just gonna run this thing into the ground and get a drop bar, carbon fork style gravel bike in a year or so
data.author: Derek Mills

data.text: You can always cut the bars down...or do what I do....get a set of bar-ends and run them in-board as a second more "aero" position.....psudo-TT position. For me and my setup, that's what I run and its quite comfortable. I have a lot of gravel sections that connect the trails so huge chunks of miles are spent on those bar-ends... old setup I rode for a few yrs...
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: My newer setup is out closer to brakes so I just use the bar-end and the brake as the place for the hands and my hands rest on the bars.
